Topic.Title: Article on Bezos & Wash Post in the New Yorker

Message.Msg: On the contrary, Amazon absolutely needs it to go through or it is in deep trouble. Even without the expansion, Amazon was going to be forced to collect taxes because it has gotten so large, where smaller and specialized players will not draw the attention of state governments. So, if it doesn't pass, many online competitors will enjoy the same tax subsidy vis a vis Amazon as it had versus brick and mortar. That will have a huge impact on big ticket, high value density items (saving 10% tax on $1K purchase) and leave Amazon with low value added, low density items (which incidentally is why Prime's selection bias is a tail event waiting to happen as well).

Topic.Title: AMZN CFO and VP also are dumping shares

Message.Msg: Best Buy has been doing well over the last year, that means Amazon's business model avoiding sales taxes is unwinding as more and more states catch on to how many $$$ they're losing and how many bricks n' mortar stores and employees Bozos is putting out of business

Topic.Title: Longs look to aapl to see the future 700 to 380 in the blink of an eye

Message.Msg: "aapl has gone from hypergrowth to a few qtrs of marching in place. The market severely punished them for this." First off, the market for one stock is not the same for another. Apple attracts a different type of investor. And the way the CEO manages expectations is different. Apple's shareholders were conditioned to be short-term oriented partly due to Moore's Law and product cycle and partly because their advantage in one product cycle was always short-lived it was easy for others (Samsung, etc.) to copy enough of what Apple did in innovation to render them close to generic in the next cycle without true innovation. Expectations for continuous innovation were too high. They failed to meet those expectations. Without Jobs this does not come as a great surprise to some. Amazon has managed expectations in a different way with a much longer runway and large investment cycles of several years rather than 18 months. "the market has ignored a model that has no proven record of earnings in favor of trusting that as revenue increases earnings will follow." Actually, they do have a good record but if you are short-term oriented then you haven't been around long enough to be able to discern the pattern. See my next reply to nanobrain techstrategy for the details on this.

Topic.Title: a CEO should make hundreds of millions of dollars so they concentrate 100% on the company's business

Message.Msg: Capital expenditures $million 2009 __ $373 2010 __ $979 2011 __ $1811 2012 __ $3785 With a fulfillment network that may have gone from 3.7x in additional capacity to 37x (in line with capex increases), a 10 fold increase, some would be pretty impressed to see that gross fulfillment had only gone up according to your figures 20 basis points with most of the additions probably at still low optimization levels at this stage. Your comparison only has significance if capex were flat after 2009 or if the build out was targeting short-term demand neither of which every knows is the case.

Topic.Title: a CEO should make hundreds of millions of dollars so they concentrate 100% on the company's business

Message.Msg: When you are planning for a cycle of several years you always begin with lots of extra capacity to grow into and the greater the growth the greater the disparity between the initial years of the cycle and the peak years. You will see this if you examine the previous two cycles prior to this one, but of course since it won't fit conveniently into the template you've devised to prop up your position with, I suspect you will not bother with this exercise. Amazon has the benefit of the largest richest data set from hundreds of millions of online shoppers on which to base its forecasts. I'd suggest Santos would understand what they were planning for and why so much capacity needed to be put in place at such a pace. It is more than amusing to see one ignorant poster with virtually no data try and second guess them.

Topic.Title: a CEO should make hundreds of millions of dollars so they concentrate 100% on the company's business

Message.Msg: 1) Your second paragraphs presumes Amazon has properly forecast the macro economy and the ultimate health of the US consumer. If we head into recession, then it will have locked in massive fixed costs into an environment of contraction. Couple that with the impact of gift cards and working capital changes and you have a recipe for disaster. 2) Blindly looking at similarities with previous "cycles" is a classic affirmation bias. There are a great many material difference in the macro/global context. Operating cash flow margin should be increasing and not increasing if your claims were true... It isn't. Here's the "awesome" performance on that metric: 2012 6.84% 2011 8.12% 2010 10.22% 2009 13.44% 2008 8.85% 2007 9.47% 2006 6.55% 2005 8.63% 2004 8.18% 2003 7.45% On a TTM basis, it is 6.77%, which is very close to decade lows. In 2013, it is negative and AMZN will need a MASSIVE Q4 for it to be positive for the year. Impartial readers will find that the operating cash flow margin tracks much more closely with my analysis than your "investment cycle" BS. The reason is that Amazon is RESPONDING to the changing cost structure that has moved against its business model (based upon fundamental economics) and is trying to reduce the disadvantage over time...

Topic.Title: Jeff B selling more shares

Message.Msg: HH: Did you see my earlier post on operating cash flow margin over the past decade? I have LOTS more fundamental analysis that clearly demonstrates the stories WS has been telling on this are just that -- stories. The market is more imbalanced that it has even been. The pain trade has been run non-stop for 9 months so that funds could dump via ETF rebalancing, but that lever is done. The disconnect is too large and is reversing, at which time the rebalancing effect force more selling of scams and buying of investments. The rebalancing will be more swift than most expect....
